MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the Atlas rocket. This is a much larger launch vehicle (LV) than the Redstone launch vehicle. It has enough thrust and propellant to take you into orbit around Earth. Today we will launch it while learning about the Checklist System.

The cockpit is the same as in Redstone so the procedures are identical. We will use the checklists found in the Mission Pad to follow the realistic procedures during preparations and ascent. Press [M] and read the BRIEFING tab for a primer on the CHECKLIST system, then click on the CHECKLISTS tab when ready.
Start by holding the countdown, we will need some extra time on preparation today. Use the Radio Command menu ([C] to toggle) and press HOLD COUNTDOWN.
The only checklist we need to follow today is the FINAL CHECKS checklist. Locate this in the Mission Pad -> CHECKLISTS, and then click it to view the checklist.
The Checklist Guidance System (CGS) is a game mechanism designed to help you with executing checklists. It will help you find the switches you need to verify or change.
Let's try to RUN a checklist using the Checklist Guidance System. Ensure the FINAL CHECKS checklist is open in the Mission Pad, then press the RUN button on the upper right corner of the Mission Pad.

When you pressed RUN, the Checklist Guidance System UI popped up, showing all the steps it needs to verify. The topmost line with a transparent green background shows the current step it is waiting for to be executed.

If the background of the current step is GREEN, as it is now, the Checklist Guidance System will by default automatically proceed to the next step if the switch is in the correct position. This auto proceed feature can be disabled in the REALISM SETTINGS.

The auto-proceed feature basically just press the checkbox button on the right side for you when the game detects that the step has been completed. If you disable the auto-proceed system, you will need to press this button manually after performing the step.

Most of the steps in a checklist supports the auto-proceed feature. However, there are some that will need you to press the check mark manually. These are usually related to checking values, performing radio tests, and so on.
Basically, if the background of the current step is FLASHING, it means that you will need to manually press the check mark to proceed to the next item in the checklist. You will try this soon.

Resume the countdown and then try to complete the first step in the checklist. With auto-proceed enabled, the checklist will automatically move to the next item. If this item is already in the correct position, it will move to the next immediately.

Follow each of the steps in the Checklist Guidance UI to complete the checklist. When you reach the RADIO CHECK steps, the active line will flash. At this point, use the Radio Command menu ([C] to toggle) and press RADIO CHECK. When complete, press the check mark on the Checklist System UI. Press ROGER when the checklist is complete.
Now, go back on the checklist menu and select the ASCENT checklist. You should read through this before ignition to get familiar with it, then use timescale to ignition.
Liftoff! Monitor the gauges you learned about in Lesson 2 (Battery Voltage, Fuel, Oxygen, Altitude, g-force).
Another step in the Atlas ascent is the booster stage. This is considered a half-stage, and will only remove some weight as our two booster engines used for the initial ascent are no longer needed.

There goes the booster stage. Another little feature worth mentioning is the Current Objective feature (toggle using [C] - visible with the Radio Command menu. This shows you what the mission is waiting for, to be able to proceed.
Once the tower separates, we will do an additional step to prevent the retro engines to jettison accidentally.
Ok, the tower is gone, you are about halfway to orbit. The Sustainer Engine is now powering you for the final journey.
To prevent the retro engines to jettison by accident or failure, we set the AUTO RETRO JETT switch to OFF (right)

Good, then disconnect the power by opening the circuit using the Retro Jett fuse on the right side of the main panel. A circuit breaker has 3 positions, 1 (up), OFF (middle) and 2 (down). Set it to OFF.
Great, by doing this, you will have some additional security around your retro engines. They are your only tool to get back to Earth once you are in orbit.

As you work through checklists, you might find the need to move it around the screen. This can be done by finding a spot on it that does not have an active UI element such as a button, scroll view, input field etc, then press and hold the Left Mouse Button and drag it around. This applies to almost any in-game window.
For the rest of the ascent, monitor the instruments and try to learn as you are ascending into orbit. The lesson ends on capsule separation.
Cap sep! Good job, this concludes this lesson. You can end the mission using the ESC menu.

Title: Tutorial 3 - Checklists and Atlas Ascent
Description: In this mission, you will use what you learned in the two previous lessons to launch the Atlas into space, and understand how the checklists work in your mission pad.
BriefingText:
BRIEFING

Preparing the Atlas for launch is the same procedure as in the Redstone (Lesson 1 and 2). The ascent is slightly different as there is an additional half-stage that needs to separate before tower launch, and the final ascent before capsule separation. The ascent takes 5 minutes to reach orbital velocity.

CHECKLIST SYSTEM
The checklist system has been designed to provide you with all the checklists needed to fly and operate all the spacecrafts in Reentry. All checklists are available from the CHECKLISTS tab of the Mission Pad. The checklist page has a few sections used to categorize checklists.
You can open a checklist by clicking on it. This will show the checklist text, and you can start reading through it. You can press [M] to toggle the mission pad while you perform a checklist, or drag the checklist elsewhere to give some more real estate to the panel so you can work with it side-by-side.

Most checklists has a RUN button and a BACK button. BACK will bring you back to the checklist selection. RUN will start a Checklist Guide System to help you through it. A switch highlighter will walk you through the checklist, highlighting out-of-place switches. The UI will show that step in the checklist you are at, and what switch needs attention.
In the Checklist Guide UI, the top line is the current checklist step needing attention, and the following lines are the queue of the next checklist items waiting for their turn. On the top line, the check button will tell the checklist system to move to the next line in the queue, completing the current line.

By default, the Checklist System is configured to automatically proceed to the next line when a switch is set to the correct position (basically pressing the checkbox for you). You can disable this auto-proceed feature from the REALISM SETTINGS. If disabled, switches in the correct position will be highlighted in green, and you need to confirm to continue.

There are two different checklist lines. One is a check to see if a control is in the correct position (such as a switch needed to be set to the UP position), or a fuse that needs to be closed.
Another type are manual steps. These steps are usually instructional (such as Perform a Radio Check, set up system X, ensure an instruments reads something). These lines have a flashing blue and green backdrop in the Checklist Guide UI. You need to manually click the check button to continue.

The Checklist Guide UI checkbox button has a bindable hot-key to it, and is by default assigned to the keyboard button [T]. Pressing [T] will proceed the checklist to the next item in line.
